stem: The clinic nurse is reviewing the EHR for a client on clozapine therapy. Based on the client's current presentation, indicate whether each nursing action is appropriate or inappropriate.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
09:00: Client (29y/o male) presents to the outpatient clinic reporting a sore throat, dry cough, and fatigue for 48 hours. He has been taking Clozapine 300 mg daily for 6 months. 
09:15: Client states, 'I feel like I have the flu, but it's getting harder to swallow.' 
09:30: Nurse notes the client appears pale and lethargic. Small ulcerations are visible on the oral mucosa.

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content:
09:45 (STAT): 
- WBC: 1,400/μL (Normal: 4,500–11,000) 
- Absolute Neutrophil Count (ANC): 350/μL (Normal: > 1,500) 
- Clozapine Level: Therapeutic range.

tabs.title: REMS Program Protocol
tabs.content: Any client on Clozapine with an ANC < 500 must have the medication immediately discontinued and be monitored for infection. Re-challenge is only permitted after hematological recovery and specialist consultation.

rows.text: Administer acetaminophen and advise the client to return if symptoms worsen in 48 hours
Obtain blood, urine, and sputum cultures as ordered
Explain to the client that the medication will be resumed once the WBC is > 3,000

rationale.correct: Clozapine-induced agranulocytosis is a medical emergency. The medication MUST be stopped immediately (r1). Due to the high risk of sepsis from neutropenia (ANC 350), protective isolation (r2) and cultures (r4) are necessary. Sending the client home with only an antipyretic (r3) is dangerous malpractice. Resuming the med (r5) is complex and requires specialized REMS clearance; the nurse should not give false hope of resumption during the acute crisis.
clinicalPearls: Any 'flu-like' symptom on Clozapine is Agranulocytosis until proven otherwise.
The ANC is the most important lab for Clozapine; if it drops below 500, the drug is stopped forever for most patients.
Agranulocytosis usually occurs in the first 6 months of therapy.

questionTrap.trap: Believing that the therapeutic Clozapine level means the drug is 'safe'.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that agranulocytosis is an adverse reaction (idiosyncratic), not necessarily a dose-dependent toxicity.

mnemonic.title: Clozapine Cues
mnemonic.expansion: C-Clozapine. L-Low WBC. O-Order ANC. Z-Zero immune system.
